Law of Composition

A law of composition on a set $M$ is a map from $M \times M$ to $M$. It is characterized by the assignment $(a, b) \longmapsto a \cdot b$ for $(a, b) \in M \times M$, and in many cases, the image of a given pair $(a, b)$ is written as a "product" $a \cdot b$ or $ab$.
Right Coset
Let $G$ be a group and $H$ a subgroup of $G$. A right coset of $H$ in $G$ is a subset of $G$ of the form $Ha = \{ha; h \in H\}$, where $a \in G$.
Coefficient of a Polynomial

Given a polynomial f=
sum a_i X^i in R[X], the i-th coefficient a_i is called the coefficient of degree i.
Principal Ideal Domain
A ring $R$ is called a principal ideal domain if it is an integral domain and every ideal of $R$ is principal.
Euclidean domain

An integral domain $R$ is called a Euclidean domain if it admits a map $\delta: R-\{0\} \longrightarrow \mathbb{N}$ making possible Euclidean division in $R$ in the following sense: Given elements $f, g \in R, g \neq 0$, there are elements $q, r \in R$ such that $f=q g+r$, where $\delta(r)<\delta(g)$ or $r=0$.
Residue class module
The residue class module M/N of an A-module M by a submodule N is defined analogously to the quotient space in vector spaces, where M/N consists of the cosets of N in M.
Galois Group of a Polynomial Splitting Fields
The Galois group of a polynomial equation is the group of automorphisms of the splitting field of the polynomial that fix the base field. These automorphisms permute the roots of the polynomial.
Degree of a Field Extension

Let $K \subset L$ be a field extension. The vector space dimension $[L: K]:=\operatorname{dim}_{K} L$ is called the degree of $L$ over $K$. The field extension is called finite or infinite, depending on whether $[L: K]$ is finite or infinite.
Algebraic subset

An algebraic subset of \(\bar{K}^{n}\) defined over \(K\) is the set of common zeros in \(\bar{K}^{n}\) of the polynomials belonging to a subset \(E\) of the polynomial ring \(K[X]=K\left[X_{1}, \ldots, X_{n}\right]\). It is denoted as \(V(E)\).
Noetherian ring

A ring \(R\) is called Noetherian if every ascending chain of ideals \(\mathfrak{a}_{1} \subset \mathfrak{a}_{2} \subset \ldots \subset R\) becomes stationary after finitely many steps, or equivalently, every ideal of \(R\) is finitely generated.
Normalizer
Let $G$ be a group and $S \subset G$ a subset. The normalizer of $S$ in $G$ is given by $N_{S}=\{x \in G ; x S=S x\}$.
Inheritance_Analysis

Generalization_Specialization_Relationsh.Explanation: A Euclidean domain (ID: 4) is a specialization of a Principal Ideal Domain (ID: 3) because every Euclidean domain is a Principal Ideal Domain. This is due to the fact that in a Euclidean domain, every ideal can be generated by a single element, which is a defining property of Principal Ideal Domains.
